entry.title: How to Use Parameters and Imported Archives in SAP CPI Message Mapping
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently working on a message mapping in SAP CPI and I'm not sure how to use the Parameter tab in the mapping editor. I understand it's meant for passing external values into the mapping, but I’m unclear on how it behaves at runtime or how to bind it properly from the iFlow.

Also, I’d love to understand how Imported Archives work in this context. Can we use custom Java functions from these archives inside user-defined functions (UDFs)? If so, what are the best practices for organizing and referencing them?

Any examples or insights from your experience would be really helpful. Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Resource Injection Failed: Error while pushing files. Cause: Request not supported. CPI error.
entry.content: Hello, I'm new to Cloud Integration. I'm getting an error when pushing the changes from MIG to Cloud iFlow.  "Resource Injection Failed: Error while pushing files. Cause: Request not supported". Please help!

entry.title: IDOCs failing in SAP system : IDoc: XXX Status: Error passing data to port | Problem with SOAP class
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We have numerous IDOC-based scenarios between SAP and SAP Integration Suite.

We have recently noticed that a few IDocs fail in the SAP system with the message:

Status Text: IDoc: <Idoc number> Status: Error passing data to port

T100 Text: Problem with SOAP class

 

In SRT_LOG, there are entries as follows: 

  • The SOAP IDoc application could not be started successfully.
  • The problem occurred in the method call: execute_processing
  • 1007:SRT: Unsupported xstream found: ("HTTP Code 404 : Not Found")

SRT_LOG (Original XML Error)

There are other successful IDocs being sent at the same time to the SAP IS interface. This seems to me like a temporary connectivity issue between SAP and SAP IS, but I need your expert advice on how it can be identified and fixed to avoid such issues.

Regards,

Prajeet

entry.title: SAP ERP (ECC 6.0 on RISE) Integration with DRC Peppol Exchange – Questions for Belgium Setup
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

This is my first time implementing the integration between SAP ERP and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) for Peppol Exchange, following SAP’s official documentation:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-edition/sap-document-and-reporting-compliance-cloud-edition/integrating-peppol-exchange-with-sap-erp?locale=en-US

However, I find the documentation quite high-level — it doesn’t go deep enough into the technical aspects, and I’m a bit confused about certain configuration points.

Context

I’m currently implementing the integration between SAP ERP ECC 6.0 (SAP RISE) and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) – Peppol Exchange for Belgium (BE).

So far, all the main configuration tasks have been completed:

  • The eDocument Cockpit is fully configured and working correctly in SAP ECC.

  • SAP DRC Peppol Exchange is deployed on SAP BTP (region: Frankfurt).

  • The ERP system is hosted on SAP RISE (region: Virginia).

  • The Cloud Connector is configured and connected to the corresponding BTP subaccount.

  • The Service Binding and Destination (DRC_PEPPOL) were successfully created in BTP.

  • A communication user with all necessary authorizations (SAP_BC_WEBSERVICE_SERVICE_USER, EDO_*, etc.) has been created.

  • The service endpoint in SOAMANAGER has been correctly configured and exposed according to SAP’s documentation at the following path:
    /sap/bc/srt/rfc/sap/dcppushservice/<xxx>/dcppushservice/pushrequest.

Despite all this, the connection between the ERP and the DRC Cloud Peppol service still cannot be established.
Ping tests return errors such as NIEHOST_UNKNOWN, NIECONN_REFUSED, or “Service Unreachable.”

At this point, I’m not sure whether the issue is related to:

  • Certificate or trust configuration between ERP and BTP,

  • A network limitation due to the cross-region setup (RISE Virginia ↔ BTP Frankfurt),

  • Or something missing in the Peppol participant configuration within the DRC instance.

Additionally, I’m unsure whether I should ask the client to explicitly allow outbound communication from the DRC Cloud service binding (created in BTP) through SAP’s internal firewall so that the ERP system can reach the endpoint.
If so, I would appreciate guidance on how this should be done — whether it should be managed directly in BTP Cockpit, via a SAP support ticket, or if it is enabled automatically once the binding is created.

Finally, the client assumes that XML ↔ UBL transformations must be handled via SAP Integration Suite (CPI), but based on my understanding, the standard SAP DRC solution should already manage these conversions internally.

1 Connection between RISE (Virginia) and BTP (Frankfurt)

Given that the ERP (RISE) and BTP environments are hosted in different regions, do I need to configure an additional SAP Cloud Connector or any special setup to enable secure communication between the two?
Or is the standard connection through the Service Binding and Destination configuration sufficient for DRC Cloud to reach the on-premise ERP?

2 eDocument Format and UBL/BIS 3.0 Transformation

According to SAP’s documentation, Peppol requires UBL BIS 3.0-compliant documents.
My main questions are:

  • Does the standard DRC solution automatically handle the XML → UBL BIS 3.0 transformation when sending eDocuments from SAP ERP to Peppol?

  • Conversely, when receiving documents from Peppol, does DRC automatically convert UBL BIS → XML so that it can be consumed by SAP ERP?

  • If these transformations are not handled natively, what’s the recommended approach to implement them?
    Specifically, how can I connect SAP DRC Cloud with SAP Integration Suite (iFlow) to intercept and transform the payload (UBL/XML) before it reaches the ERP?
    (I would really appreciate if anyone has implemented a similar setup or could share a best-practice example.)

I would also appreciate any insights on special settings that should be considered in the eDocument Cockpit for sending and/or receiving documents.

3. RISE and ECC Connectivity Considerations

The client refers to their system as SAP RISE, but technically the backend is SAP ECC 6.0.
Are there any official SAP guidelines or technical notes describing the recommended configuration for this hybrid scenario (RISE + DRC Cloud) — especially regarding trust setup, certificates, or communication channels?
The existing SAP documentation seems too generic, so any deeper or experience-based guidance would be very helpful.

Thank you in advance for your help and insights!
Any detailed documentation, SAP Notes, or examples from similar Belgium Peppol implementations would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: How to integrate with SAP Commerce with ease?
entry.content:
If you are developing eCommerce app or software, you will have to deal with difficulties when developing eCommerce integrations. The more connections you need, the more challenges you will face. If you want to integrate with SAP Commerce and simplify integration development, you can use a ready-made solution like API2Cart. It provides a unified API, so you can easily connect to SAP Commerce and other eCommerce platforms at once. You will be able to get, add, update and sync store data such as orders, products, customers, etc. 

Save your time and resources and focus on other business goals while API2Cart takes care of integrations.

entry.title: Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable in Product API error
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and trying to perform a POST operation using the Product (API_PRODUCT_2) API.
However, I’m receiving the following error response:

{
  "error": {
    "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
    "message": "Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable",
    "target": "_ProductPurchaseOrderText(Product='102010000009',TextObjectType='BEST',Language='EN')",
    "details": [
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductProcurement"
      },
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductPlant(Product='102010000009',Plant='CN7A')/_ProductPlantProcurement"
      }
    ],
    "innererror": {
      "ErrorDetails": {
        "@SAP__common.Application": {
          "ComponentId": "LO-MD-MM",
          "ServiceRepository": "SRVD_A2X",
          "ServiceId": "API_PRODUCT_2",
          "ServiceVersion": "0001"
        },
        "@SAP__common.TransactionId": "86545C3DDA130010E0068E7D20C1703B",
        "@SAP__common.Timestamp": "20251009154237.258522",
        "@SAP__common.ErrorResolution": {
          "Analysis": "Use ADT feed reader 'SAP Gateway Error Log' or run transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG on SAP Gateway hub system and search for entries with the timestamp above for more details",
          "Note": "See SAP Note 1797736 for error analysis"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

My Question:

  • Why are these entities (PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT, PRODUCTPROCUREMENT, PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT) not maintainable through the post API?

  • Are there any restrictions in the Public Cloud Edition for maintaining these sub-entities via API?

  • Is there an alternative API or approach to update these product procurement or purchase order text details?

 

I’ve already checked the payload structure and API reference documentation, and the JSON is valid. The base product entity is being read successfully — the error occurs only during the POST operation.

Any insights or SAP Notes related to this behavior would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance,
Janarthanan R.

entry.title: S/4HANA to Bank SFTP via CPI – AL11 vs Client SFTP
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are integrating S/4HANA Private Cloud with a Bank SFTP through SAP CPI (PGP encryption handled in CPI). An ABAP program in S/4HANA will generate and place the output file either on AL11 or a client SFTP location. Considering two options:
1️. S/4 → AL11 → CPI → Bank SFTP (BASIS mounts SFTP on AL11)
2. S/4 → Client SFTP → CPI → Bank SFTP

Which approach is SAP-recommended / best practice? Does SAP provides any free SFTP server for such use? If we mount external client SFTP to AL11, does it makes any sense as eventually we will be picking the file from SFTP server.

Thanks,

Mohit

entry.title: Performance Difference Observed Between IIB and SAP IS – Database Query Response Time
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am an IBM Integration Bus (IIB) resource currently working on a migration project where I’m assisting the SAP Integration team by providing the IIB landscape and architecture required for migration to SAP Integration Suite (SAP IS).

As part of a small performance comparison and feasibility test, I simulated a very basic database interaction scenario in SAP IS and observed a significant difference in response time compared to IIB.  I would appreciate guidance on whether this is expected behavior or caused by trial environmental limits.
[Note]:I also tried interacting with IBM MQ SAAS and compared SAP IS and IBM IIB results, again, ending with similar situation(not covered in this Post).

Test setup and observations:

  • I created a SAP HANA Cloud (trial) database for testing.
  • Added a single test table containing only 3 rows of static data.
  • Built a simple SAP iFlow with:
    • An HTTP Sender Adapter to invoke the flow.
    • Three simple SELECT statements(3 calls) to the HANA DB (no transforms, no mappings).
    • No other processing steps.
  • When I invoke the iFlow via HTTP, the total response time is around 7–10 seconds consistently.
  • For comparison, I implemented the same logic in IIB (connected to an SQL Server) and observed typical response times of 100–200 ms. (Occasionally the first call after a long idle takes ~500–700 ms.)

Additional context:

  • The SAP IS trial account is hosted in the US East (VA)-AWS region, whereas the SAP HANA Cloud trial database is in the Singapore Azure region.
  • In the IIB scenario, both IIB runtime and the SQL Server database are co-located in the same data center, likely explaining the ultra-low latency observed there.
  • The http request is initiated(for both tests) using postman from Cloud PC somewhere in US.
  • I understand that cross-region latency can contribute to higher response times, but a difference of 7–10 seconds vs 100–200 miliseconds still feels unusually high for such a lightweight query.

Primary question:

Is the observed delay in SAP IS due to the HANA Cloud trial environment (resource throttling, cold starts, or connection setup time on every request sent), or is there inherent overhead in SAP IS runtime for such DB interactions?

Specific areas where guidance would help:

  • Does SAP IS / DB adapter use connection pooling or persistent connections to the database?
  • Are there known limitations in trial HANA or IS tenants that can cause high round-trip time?
  • Are there runtime or adapter-level settings to minimize latency for repeated database operations?
  • Would response time improve noticeably in a production-grade tenant (same region) setup?

I would greatly appreciate any insights, documentation references, or configuration tips to help understand and potentially improve this response time behavior.

-Dhruv

entry.title: Issue Migrating Integrations to SAP Integration Suite via "Migrate Process Orchestration Artifacts"
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I’m currently facing an issue while trying to migrate integrations from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite using the Migrate Process Orchestration Artifacts tool.

Has anyone in the community faced a similar issue? Are there any additional prerequisites or configurations required to have the integration patterns show up correctly in this step?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Issue While posting Idoc in SAP ECC- SAP BTP-CI
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am facing one issue while posting IDoc in SAP ECC through BTP-CI. However everything is working fine in CI-TEST  but in CI- QA its giving issue

My scenario is SFTP-->BTP CI-->SAP ECC( IDoc)

While posting IDoc in QA SAP ECC its failing due to below error;

Error Details
org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: Response was of unexpected text/html ContentType. Incoming portion of HTML stream: (none)
 
In SAP ECC i checked SICF service is activated however while registering in SRTIDOC its giving error as " Error in Change and Transport system"
As per s-note
2943773 - ESI - SRTIDOC: Error in Change and Transport System we chose second option as move the configuration through transport from lower environment to higher environment however issue still persists. 
 
Can anyone please help here?
In dev its working fine but in QA its failing.
 
Regards
Ankur Chopra

entry.title: Connection Issue Between SAP BTP Trial and S/4HANA On-Premise via Cloud Connector
entry.content:
Hi All,

I’m currently configuring the connectivity between our SAP BTP free trial account and our S/4HANA on-premise system using the Cloud Connector. After completing the setup, I tried to validate the connection between the cloud and on-premise systems, but I encountered an error.

Upon checking the related SAP Note, it seems that the issue might be due to a possible spelling mistake in the host name or a connectivity issue with the internal host.

I have verified that the internal hostname and port are correct, and I also checked in SICF in on-premise system to ensure the correct internal host and port are maintained. However, the connection is still not working. I’m using an HTTPS connection.

Could you please help me resolve this issue?

BR/Kannan.

entry.title: SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest for creating a product with classification
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

We need to create products with related classifications and characteristics via API in S/4 Hana Cloud Public. For with purpose we use standard SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest ( https://api.sap.com/api/PRODUCTMDMBULKREPLICATEREQUEST/overview ). 

But we have a problem: when we're consuming the web service from ABAP Environment ( from custom class from Eclipse ), we get errors  in SOAP Log Message:

 

Log Messages

 
Consumer:
  • Web service processing error; more details in the web service error log on provider side (UTC timestamp 20251027114623; Transact
  • soap-env : http://schemas.xmlsoap. org/soap/envelope/
  • faultcode : soap-env:Server
  • faultstring : Web service processing error; more details in the web service error log on provider side (UTC timestamp 20251027114623; Transa ... Show More
  • lang : en
     
    Provider:
    SRT: Plain SOAP: Reliable messaging (RM) configured, but consumer sends QoS BE request.
     We are trying to call the SOAP web service within SAP: Source and Target both are S4 HANA public cloud system.

 

Here are our actions step-by-step:

1. Created a Communication User in the Maintain Communication Users app  in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition.

2. Created a communication system in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition and added as inbound communication user created in step 1

3.  Created a communication arrangement based on the communication scenario SAP_COM_0009. Deactivate all Outbound Services. And then downloaded WSDL file of Product Master - Replicate from Client to SAP S/4HANA Cloud

4. Created in ADT a service consumption model for the targeted web service from the metadata file from step 3.

5. Created in ADT  an outbound service.

6. Created in ADT  a communication scenario and assign the outbound service to it. Chose the Authentication Methods Basic and X.509.

7.  Then in Communication Arrangements app created another communication arrangement based on our custom communication scenario, as well as a new communication system and an outbound communication user from step 1.

8.  Checked connection: we get "The ping of the outbound service was successful".

9. For the implementation of the outbound call, we used the code sample copied earlier from the service consumption model

I would really appreciate any help. Many thanks in advance for your help.

entry.title: IDOC integration of SAP backends - SAP Cloud Integration (Int. Suite)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have an inbound IDOC interface using SAP Integration Suite(Cloud Integration) .. SOAP to IDOC is the scenario where sender is a web services.. Now, our Basis team is declining to enable SICF on SAP backend and adding "/" path as it is against our organization security hardening guidelines.. We are using Cloud Connector obviously.. below are the steps implemented :-

1. All communication will flow exclusively through the SAP Cloud Connector(SCC) , establishing a secure, avoiding direct internet exposure of the backend. Strict firewall rules maintained to allow only essential communication between the Cloud Connector and the SAP backend. All communication utilizes standard, auditable HTTPS/TLS 1.2+ protocols, securing data transmission end-to-end. The SCC configuration explicitly exposes only the virtual host and the single path: /sap/bc/srt/idoc.

2. Secure ICF Service Activation on SAP Backend : Only the specific /sap/bc/srt/idoc ICF service will be activated, with debugging/tracing disabled in production.. Debugging and tracing features are explicitly disabled on the SICF service in all Production environments.

3. A dedicated, non-dialog user is created with a single-purpose role ..

SAP Support documentation confirms that the use of the '/' value in S_SERVICE does not act as a security wildcard for explicitly defined Web Services. This guarantees that the technical user is strictly contained and cannot execute other general services. Please see below screenshot of email from SAP team regarding the same. Could you please add if anything important is missing here to establish secure architecture? Any chances that our Organization Hardening tam still rejects ?

Regards,

Ramu.

entry.title: EntraID Token Propagation via SAP Approuter for Azure destinations?
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

My question is related to an integration case, where I want to privately integrate data from a SAP backend to an Azure Storage account.

Situation: Write Data from the backend (S/4) via Integration Suite to a private Storage account. I am using SAP private link service (PLS) to be able to reach the private endpoint of the azure storage account, the destination call must be made via an SAP approuter, as there is no direct way of calling the PLS destination directly in SAP Integration Suite.

Problem: Even though the approuter supports token propagation, i could not figure out a way of chaining the propagation, so that I authenticate at the Approuter protected by Cloud IAS (with MS Entra as corp. IdP), translate the token to back to the correct format, that is then presented to the Storage account. The issue lies in the audience claim of the JWT token. For authenticating against the storage account the scope has to match the targeted azure resource (https://storage.azure.com in this case), the claim required by the approuter, however, is the client id of the Cloud IAS application. 

Question(s): Is this integration case even supported by SAP Cloud IAS / MS Entra Token Propagation in combination with using the SAP approuter? My assumption was, since all resources are protected by the same Entra Id tenant, it must be possible to propagate/translate the token to the respective resources?

Another interesting questions would be, if there is a planned feature to support Private Link Service directly via Integration Suite instead of the work-around via the approuter?


Thanks a lot in advance for any response. 

Best Regards 
Matthias

entry.title: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JDBC
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)  
 
JDBC – JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY 
 
Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API : 
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access. 
 
Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging 
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. 
 
Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).  
 
For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section. 
 
Prerequisites: 

  1. SAP DataSphere – Subscribed account (⚠ Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported) 
  1. SAP Integration Suite – Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported) 

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide : 
 

Step 

Action / Notes 

1. Create a Space 

DataSphere → Space Management → New Space → Name it → Create. 

2. Create Table / Analytical Model 

Data Builder → In your Space → New → Table or Analytical Model → define fields & data types → Save & Publish. 
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. * 

3. Prepare / Load Data 

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration. 

4. Note Schema & Object Names 

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use. 
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name * 

5. Decide Where to Create DB User 

If HANA Cloud → use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB → use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin. 
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session* 

6. Create JDBC DB User 

DB admin tool → Security/Users → New User → set username & strong password → Save. 
*Check Active status of User* 

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user 

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign. 

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details 

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com 
Format for CPI JDBC Material: 
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true 

 
SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide : 
 
Create a Package & Artifact 

  • In CPI → Design → Create a new package → Add an integration flow artifact. 
  • ✅ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts. 
     

Go to Monitoring → JDBC Material 

  • In CPI → Monitor → Integrations and APIs → Manage Security → JDBC Material

     

     
  • → Add JDBC Data Source. → Select HANA cloud  

     

     
     
  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true). 

     

     
  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere). 

     

     
  • Save and deploy the JDBC material. 
    •  

    Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

    • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter → select the JDBC data source created.
    • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I’m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

     


    Step 1: Timer Start
     In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule → None → On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

     


    Step 2: Content Modifier
    Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
     SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

     



    Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
         → Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
    → JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

     


    Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

     



    References :

    CPI JDBC – XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
     link:
    https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: Guidance for Creating Sales Order from External System to SAP Public Cloud Using CPI
entry.content:
Hi SAP Exports,

I am currently working on creating a sales order from an external system dynamically. While going through various blogs and videos, I was unable to find a complete and proper document that clearly explains how to create the sales order from an external system and access the data through Postman using JSON Web Token (JWT) or OAuth 2.0 authentication.

Could you please guide me on:

  • Which authentication method (JWT or OAuth 2.0) is easier to implement for this scenario?

  • The step-by-step process to create the sales order, starting from the external system up to testing in Postman.

  • How to handle the payload and mapping of fields.

I have already created the communication arrangements and am using the standard API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub (A2X). However, I am currently stuck at the field mapping and payload creation stage.

Additionally, could you please clarify whether Groovy scripts are required for creating the sales order dynamically, and which approach is recommended — hardcoding or dynamic creation?

Thank you very much for your time and guidance.
